column5: "FIG. 3. Adaptation of action potential frequency in whole-cell recordings during 300-ms/200-pA current steps in 2 different GCs [granule cells] <% 1000 %>. Top, recorded 8 min after intraluminal membrane rupture, from a cell without exogenous calcium buffers in the recording electrode. Bottom, from a cell recorded with the calcium chelator BAPTA [1,2-bis (2-aminophenoxy)ethane-N,N,Np,Np-tetraacetic acid] in the electrode solution (11 mM BAPTA- 1 mM CaCl2), 10 min after membrane rupture. column5: "Figure 8. Changes in spike amplitude and duration during repetitive ﬁring. A, Data from a normally adapting  (TML [total molecular layer] cell <% 1004 %>;  top  row) and a nonadapting (GCL [granule cell layer] cell; middle row) interneuron and from a granule cell (bottom row) [in the dentate gyrus]. For each cell, a spike train elicited by injected depolarizing current (left column), the superimposed traces of the ﬁrst (solid line) and ﬁfth (dotted line) spike of the train (middle column), and a graph of spike duration (A.P. [action potential] Duration) versus spike number (A. P. Number) during the train is shown. The depolarizing current injection was 0.2 nA for the interneurons and 0.14 nA for the granule cell. Note that in the nonadapting cell neither the spike amplitude nor duration changed during the train. In contrast, marked changes in both of these parameters were apparent in all other cell types tested. B, Comparison of the effect of repetitive ﬁring on the amplitude  of the action potential. The bar graph depicts the amplitude of the ﬁfth action potential of a train expressed as a percentage of the ﬁrst action potential of the train in each of the three classes of interneurons and granule cells. In this ﬁgure, bars and error bars represent the mean 6 SEM (**p , 0.01). C, Comparison of the effect of repetitive ﬁring on the duration of the action potential. The bar graph represents the duration of the ﬁfth spike of the train as a percentage of the duration of the ﬁrst spike (**p , 0.01; ***p , 0.001). Note the striking lack of a change in the spike duration in nonadapting cells as compared with all other cell types."
column9: Mott DD, Turner DA, Okazaki MM, Lewis DV.
column10: Interneurons of the dentate-hilus border of the rat dentate gyrus: morphological and electrophysiological heterogeneity.
column15: In the Hippocampome, the action potential amplitude (APampl) is defined as the peak voltage relative to the firing threshold potential (Vthresh).

column5: "NGFCs [neurogliaform cells] <% 1007 %> had a characteristically late firing pattern, often exhibiting a ramp in membrane potential prior to firing action potentials (Fig. 3A, top trace), a resting membrane potential of -75.6 +/- 0.9 mV, a threshold of -30 +/- 1 mV, an input resistance of 147 +/- 8 MOhm, a membrane time constant of 6.81 +/- 0.36 msec, and essentially no sag (0.17 +/- 0.10 mV) in response to a -100 pA hyperpolarizing step."

column5: "Figure 10. AHPs [afterhyperpolarization] of [dentate] interneurons. A, Fast AHPs (fAHPs) from left to right are examples from a nonadapting (IML [inner molecular layer] cell <% 1009 %>), normally adapting (TML [total molecular layer] cell <% 1004 %> <% 1005 %>), and a granule cell. Note the larger amplitude of the fAHP in the nonadapting cell. The triphasic appearance of the granule cell spike afterpotential with an initial fAHP (1), followed by a depolarizing phase (2), and then a slower hyperpolarizing phase (3) can be seen to contrast with the much less complex fAHPs of the interneurons."

column18: The anatomy of axo-axonic cells in the dentate gyrus <% 1010 %> (Halasy and Somogyi 1993; Han et al. 1993; Soriano and Frotscher 1989; Soriano et al. 1990) and subfield CA1 of Ammon’s horn (Li et al. 1992a; Somogyi et al. 1983, 1985) has been addressed previously. In these studies a number of discrepancies are apparent (e.g., the extent and distribution of the axon) but these are largely attributable to differences in visualization methods. Because the present paper is largely concerned with the physiological properties of axo-axonic cells only the most salient, novel, or physiologically relevant anatomic data will be summarized.

column5: "FIG . 6. Paired morphology and physiology of a spiny hilar interneuron <% 1026 %>. ... C: voltage responses to current injections of -100 to +150 pA in 50-pA increments and -40 to +40 pA in 10-pA increments. All responses, except the 1 containing action potentials, are averages of 4–8 trials. Note that the spikes arise from a slow ramp in response to the +150-pA current injection. Presence of a larger initial depolarization in response to +100 pA suggests that a K+ current is activated by the larger current injection, which then slowly inactivates, causing the depolarizing ramp response to the +150-pA current injection. _o = 35 ms; action potential half-width 0.87 ms; sag ratio 0.81 (-100 pA response)."

column5: "Table 1. Membrane properties of granule-like neurons <% 1041 %> and granule cells in the granule cell layer [of the dentate gyrus] of pilocarpine-treated rats and saline-treated controls"
column9: Scharfman HE, Goodman JH, Sollas AL.
column10: Granule-like neurons at the hilar/CA3 border after status epilepticus and their synchrony with area CA3 pyramidal cells: functional implications of seizure-induced neurogenesis.
column15: In the Hippocampome, the action potential amplitude (APampl) is defined as the peak voltage relative to the firing threshold potential (Vthresh).
column18: Surprisingly, electrophysiological studies of EGCs [ectopic granule cells] <% 1041 %> in the hilus of pilocarpine-treated rats have shown that their intrinsic electrical properties are comparable to granule cells that are positioned normally, in the granule cell layer (GCL GCs; Scharfman et al., 2000). However, they often display spontaneous epileptiform activity, which is never recorded from normal granule cells (Scharfman et al., 2000).

column5: "Figure 2. Morphology and firing properties of CA3 GCs [granule cells] <% 2001 %>. A, Whole-cell recorded, biocytin filled, and subsequently reconstructed CA3 GC. ... A3, Accommodating firing pattern of the cell shown in A1 and A2 in response to depolarizing constant current injection. A4, Accommodating firing pattern of a DG GC."
column9: Szabadics J, Varga C, Brunner J, Chen K, Soltesz I.
column10: Granule cells in the CA3 area.

column5: "In addition, CA3 GCs [granule cells] <% 2001 %> and DG GCs displayed statistically similar hyperpolarized resting membrane potentials (78 +/- 0.5 and 77.5 +/- 0.8 mV; n = 15 and 12, respectively), relatively large input resistances (139 +/- 11 and 141 +/- 17 MOhm), and fast membrane time constants (17.1 +/- 1.8 and 18 +/- 2.1 ms), and the CA3 and DG GCs sharply differed in these properties from CA3 PCs (n = 15; resting membrane potential, -74.8 +/- 1.3 mV; CA3 PCs compared with CA3 GCs, p < 0.03; CA3 PCs compared with DG GCs, p < 0.05; input resistance, 112 +/- 9 MOhm, p < 0.05; membrane time constant, 47 +/- 6.3 ms, p < 0.003 and p < 0.0004). As expected from the differences in input resistance and membrane time constant values, the membrane capacitance of CA3 GC (11.3 +/- 1 pF; n = 15) was significantly different from that of CA3 PCs (43.2 +/- 3.6 pF; n = 15). Furthermore, similar to the spike-broadening characteristics of DG GCs and MF terminals (Geiger and Jonas, 2000), action potentials of CA3 GCs also showed a gradual broadening during action potential trains (50 Hz; half-width of the first AP was 821 +/- 29 micros, compared with the 25th at 1044 +/- 28 micros and the 50th at 1072 +/- 35 micros; p < 10^-8 and p < 0.0005, respectively)."
column9: Szabadics J, Varga C, Brunner J, Chen K, Soltesz I.
column10: Granule cells in the CA3 area.
column18: All necessary morphological evidence is present in this self-same publication.

column5: "FIG. 3. Comparison of ﬁring patterns in giant cells and CA3 pyramidal cells. ... B: time course of instantaneous ﬁring frequency of each action potential in the train. column5: "Figure 3. Intrinsic membrane properties and the ﬁring patterns of O-LM [oriens-lacunosum moleculare] <% 2009 %> and trilaminar interneurones <% 2020 %> [in CA3] A, the ﬁring patterns and the intrinsic membrane properties of the O-LM (i, upper traces) and trilaminar (ii, upper traces) interneurones during 500 ms-long depolarizing (300 pA for both O-LM and trilaminar cells) and hyperpolarizing intrasomatic current injection (of –200 pA to –20 pA in 20-pA increments for both cell types; lower traces, Vm –70 mV). O-LM (i) but not trilaminar (ii) cell shows the clear ‘sag’ at stronger hyperpolarizing current injection (sag ratio at –200 pA was 0.73). Note sudden periods of silence in trilaminar cells during a prolonged current step and typical suppression of action potential amplitude in O-LM cells (which normally no longer discharged at > 600 pA depolarizing current injection, see D)."

column5: "Figure 5. MFs [mossy fibers] are monosynaptically connected to SLCs [spiny lucidum cells] <% 2019 %> in CA3. A, Dendritic (gray) and axonal (black) arborizations, firing pattern, the spiny dendritic surface, and immunoreactivities of a representative SLC that received monosynaptic MF inputs. Note that the SLC dendrites aligned with the stratum lucidum. Asterisk marks the severed main (presumably long distance-projecting) axon of the SLC on the surface of the slice. Circle graph indicates the relative proportion of the SLCs (shaded black in the circle graph) that received monosynaptic input from MFs of the 46 MF–SLC pairs (BIO, biocytin; ori, stratum oriens; pyr, stratum pyramidale; luc, stratum lucidum) (calibration for the firing pattern: 20 mV, 200 ms)."

column5: "Figure 3. Intrinsic membrane properties and the ﬁring patterns of O-LM [oriens-lacunosum moleculare] <% 2009 %> and trilaminar interneurones <% 2020 %> [in CA3] A, the ﬁring patterns and the intrinsic membrane properties of the O-LM (i, upper traces) and trilaminar (ii, upper traces) interneurones during 500 ms-long depolarizing (300 pA for both O-LM and trilaminar cells) and hyperpolarizing intrasomatic current injection (of –200 pA to –20 pA in 20-pA increments for both cell types; lower traces, Vm –70 mV). O-LM (i) but not trilaminar (ii) cell shows the clear ‘sag’ at stronger hyperpolarizing current injection (sag ratio at –200 pA was 0.73). Note sudden periods of silence in trilaminar cells during a prolonged current step and typical suppression of action potential amplitude in O-LM cells (which normally no longer discharged at > 600 pA depolarizing current injection, see D)."

column5: "Fig. 2. AACs [axo-axonic cells] <% 2028 %> and BCs [basket cells] are differentially involved in gamma-frequency oscillations. (A and B) Reconstructions of a recorded and biocytin-filled AAC (A) and BC (B) in the CA3 area. The axon (in black) of the AAC is found at the border of the pyramidal layer (Pyr.) and stratum oriens (Or.), where AISs [action initial segments] of pyramidal cells are localized. The light micrograph shows axo-axonic cartridges of labeled AAC along the AIS of two unstained PCs [pyramidal cells]. Asterisks mark PC somata. In contrast, the BC shows a broader distribution of the axon in the pyramidal layer and adjacent region of the strata oriens and radiatum. The high-power photomicrograph shows two PC somata surrounded by biocytin-labeled axonal baskets. Inset traces illustrate the characteristic fast-spiking discharge of the interneurons in response to 0.3 nA depolarizing current pulses. (C) Whole- cell recording from an AAC reveals that the cell discharges at a constant high frequency (left, red trace, ic) during KA-induced network gamma oscillations (black trace, LFP [local field potential]). Spectral analysis of the AAC discharge shows a sharp peak at 104 Hz (right, red curve, right y axis; mV^2/Hz), separate from the peak in the power spectrum of the extracellular oscillations (30 Hz, black curve, left y axis; microV^2/Hz). (D) Corresponding data from a BC. In contrast to the AAC, the BC discharged at gamma frequencies (30 Hz) with clear phase-locking to the oscillations. (E to G) The firing frequencies of the two types are different during network activity (E), although there was no significant difference in the mean frequency (F) and power (G) of LFP between the two sets of recordings (n = 4 and 6, respectively)."
column9: Dugladze T, Schmitz D, Whittington MA, Vida I, Gloveli T.
column10: Segregation of axonal and somatic activity during fast network oscillations.

column5: "There were no significant differences in the resting membrane potentials of [CA3] AACs [axo-axonic cells] <% 2028 %> and BCs [basket cells] (-58.0 +/- 2.8 mV vs. -56.6 +/- 2.8 mV, n = 6 and n = 10, respectively, p>0.05).  However,  these  cell  types  are  clearly  distinguishable  on  the  basis  of  their  passive  membrane  properties. AACs had significantly higher input resistances and slower membrane time constants  than BCs (182.8 +/- 35.2 MOhm and 8.9 +/- 1.3 ms vs. 96.3 +/- 13.9 MOhm and 5.3 +/- 0.7 ms, p < 0.05 for  both values). During intrasomatic current injection, both cell types discharged at high frequency,  with little adaptation of very brief action potentials (AACs: 0.69 +/- 0.06 ms, n = 4; BCs: 0.52 +/-  0.04 ms, n = 5)."

column5: "Fig. 3. Morphological identiﬁcation of presynaptic INs [interneurons] and demonstration of synaptic connections between a presynaptic MFA [ mossy ﬁber-associated] IN <% 2036 %> and a postsynaptic PC [pyramidal cell]. ... column5: "Figure 6. CA3-specific MFAs <% 2036 %> were not found to be monosynaptically innervated by MFs. column5: "Figure 7. Electrophysiological and morphological characterization of perisomatic PV[parvalbumin]-positive cells [in CA3] A, Neurolucida reconstruction of the biocytin-ﬁlled PV-positive basket cell <% 2043 %>. The soma and radial dendrites are drawn in red, whereas the axon is in black. The axonal branches from the basket cells are mainly restricted to stratum pyramidale. Hippocampal layers are depicted schematically. CA3, CA3 area; str. or., stratum oriens; str. pyr., stratum pyramidale; str. rad., stratum radiatum. The inset shows a typical response of these cells during intrasomatic depolarizing (600 nA) and hyperpolarizing (–200 pA) current injection. Note a fast ﬁring in basket cell in response to depolarizing current injection."

column5: "Fig. 1. Genetic background affects the magnitude of the AHP [of CA1 pyramidal cells] <% 4000 %>. A-C: a representative trace of the afterhyperpolarization (AHP) evoked at -60 mV (by a 50-ms current injection sufﬁcient to elicit 5 action potentials) is shown for each genetic background examined: B6 (A), F2 (B), and 129 (C). In all panels, the dashed line represents the baseline membrane potential before current injection and the triangles indicate different phases of the AHP as follows: peak AHP (pAHP; solid triangles), medium AHP (mAHP; shaded triangles), and slow AHP (sAHP; open triangles). Note that action potentials are truncated for clarity. D: group data (means +/- SE) indicating the magnitudes of the pAHP, mAHP, and sAHP in each genetic background (B6, n = 28; F2, n = 35; 129, n = 29). The asterisk indicates a signiﬁcant difference compared with B6, and the pound sign indicates a signiﬁcant difference compared with F2 (P = 0.02, 1-factor repeated-measures ANOVA [analysis of variance] with Newman-Keuls post hoc test)."

column5: "FIG. 5. Current-voltage relationships of pyramidal neurons <% 4000 %> [in CA1] and the effect of 5 mM CsCl. Top: voltage responses to various current steps. Middle: I-V plot of subthreshold responses in control (_) and in 5 mM CsCl (∆Ç). Lines were ﬁt to the linear portion of the I-V curve (-) and subsequently extrapolated (- - -). Bottom: hyperpolarizing voltage response to a -150-pA, 600-ms current injection in control (top) and 5 mM CsCl (bottom). A: RS [regular spiking] subicular neuron (subthreshold = 50-pA steps from -200 to +200 pA; suprathreshold = +250 pA); Rn (control) = 31 MOhm, Rn (Cs+) = 57 MOhm. B: WB [weak bursting] subicular neuron (subthreshold = 50-pA steps from -200 to +200 pA; suprathreshold = +250 pA); Rn (control) = 34 MOhm, Rn (Cs+) = 57 MOhm. C: SB [strong bursting] subicular neuron (subthreshold = 50-pA steps from -200 to +200 pA; suprathreshold = +300 pA); Rn (control) = 27 MOhm, Rn (Cs+) = 59 MOhm. D: CA1 neuron (subthreshold = 50-pA steps from -200 to +150 pA; suprathreshold = +200 pA); Rn (control) = 51 MOhm, Rn (Cs+) = 102 MOhm."

column5: "FIG. 6. Passive membrane and ﬁring properties of pyramidal neurons <% 4000 %> [in CA1]. ... B: half-widths of action potentials from different cell types. The 1st action potential is similar in RS [regular spiking], WB [weak bursting], and SB [strong bursting] subicular neuron, with the half-width increasing within a burst. column5: "Figure 2. PCs [pyramidal cells] <% 4000 %> and RGCs [radiatum giant cells] <% 4054 %> [in CA1] have similar intrinsic ﬁring patterns. The characteristic ﬁring response to brief (5 msec) and long (1600 msec) positive current pulses are shown in a and b, respectively. Both the PC and the RGC ﬁred a single action potential in response to brief current pulses and an accommodating train of action potentials in response to long current pulses. column5: "Figure 3. Electrophysiological characterization and perforant path-evoked excitability of NG [neurogliaform] cells <% 4011 %> [in CA1]. A, Current-clamp traces showing the results of hyperpolarizing current-clamp steps of 10, 20, and 30 pA demonstrate the low input resistance associated with NG cells, whereas a depolarizing current step (220 pA) to just beyond threshold shows the slow ramping of membrane voltage just before action potential initiation. Large depolarizing current steps, 700 and 500 pA, respectively, elicit weak accommodating spike trains (A1) and bursting spike trains (A2)."

column5: "Large-amplitude current pulses resulted in action potential discharges [from neurogliaform cells] <% 4012 %> that were either continuous, showing some degree of adaptation, or interrupted by gaps to yield spike clusters (Fig. 3A1, A2). column5: "Figure 3. Electrophysiological characterization and perforant path-evoked excitability of NG [neurogliaform] cells <% 4012 %> [in CA1]. A, Current-clamp traces showing the results of hyperpolarizing current-clamp steps of 10, 20, and 30 pA demonstrate the low input resistance associated with NG cells, whereas a depolarizing current step (220 pA) to just beyond threshold shows the slow ramping of membrane voltage just before action potential initiation. Large depolarizing current steps, 700 and 500 pA, respectively, elicit weak accommodating spike trains (A1) and bursting spike trains (A2)."

column5: "Fig. 4. Electrophysiological properties of pro-CCK[cholecystokinin]-immunopositive interneurones. Comparison of the active membrane properties of two basket cells <% 4079 %> (A and B, cell identities 271100/4, P16, and 281100/4, P17, respectively) to two Schaffer collateral-associated cells <% 4015 %> [in CA1] (C and D, cell identities 310800/1, P12, and 040900/2, P16, respectively). (A1 , C1 ) Voltage responses of a basket and Schaffer collateral-associated cell, to hyperpolarising (-100 to -25 pA) and a small depolarising (+50 and +25 pA, respectively) current steps. Voltage responses to hyperpolarising current steps in the Schaffer collateral-associated cell show a pronounced rectification, or ‘sag’, which is present to a lesser degree in the basket cell. Note how the depolarising rebound potentials at the step offset of the two largest voltage responses in the Schaffer collateral-associated cell are able to generate rebound action potentials."

column5: "Fig. 11. Properties of a pair of synaptically coupled CCK-IR [cholecystokinin-immunoreactive] Schaffer-associated cells <% 4028 %> [in CA1]. A: FITC [ﬂuorescein isothiocyanate] immunoﬂuorescence for CCK in the presynaptic cell. B: DAB [3,  3p,  5,  5p-diaminobenzidine] staining of the presynaptic cell. C: FITC immunoﬂuorescence for CCK in the postsynaptic cell. D: DAB staining of the postsynaptic cell. E: Light microscopic reconstruction of presynaptic (dark grey: soma/dendrites; light grey: axonal arbour) and postsynaptic (soma/dendrites only: black) cells. The two close appositions between presynaptic axon and postsynaptic dendrites are indicated by black dots. F: Action potentials in the presynaptic cell triggered fast IPSPs [inhibitory postsynaptic potentials] in the postsynaptic cell. G: Current injections (amplitudes as indicated) into the presynaptic cell reveal fast, deep spike afterhyperpolarizations, indicative of fast-spiking cells. After onset of the voltage responses to hyperpolarizing currents, a large sag and rebound following are noticeable. The presynaptic cell was regular-spiking (not shown). Scale bar = 50 [micro]m in D (also applies to A–C), 100 [micro]m in E."
column9: Pawelzik H, Hughes DI, Thomson AM.

column5: "In contrast to pyramidal cells, axo-axonic cells <% 4036 %>  have nonovershooting action potentials with a mean a mean amplitude of 64.1 +/- 7.1 mV ( n = 13) when measured from baseline. Measured at half-amplitude, action potentials had a mean duration of 389 +/- 86 ps"

column5: "Measurements were taken at the plateau of the voltage response and ranged from 38 to 116 MOhm. They <% 4036 %> were, on average, 73.9 +/- 23.8 MOhm"
column9: Buhl EH, Han ZS, Lörinczi Z, Stezhka VV, Karnup SV, Somogyi P.
column10: Physiological properties of anatomically identified axo-axonic cells in the rat hippocampus.

column5: "Membrane time constants were calculated from averages of typically 0.1 -nA, 200-ms hyperpolarizing pulses as the time necessary to reach e-l (63%) of the maximum voltage deflection. Axo-axonic cells had a mean time constant of 7.7 +/- 3.8 ms"<% 4036 %>
column9: Buhl EH, Han ZS, Lörinczi Z, Stezhka VV, Karnup SV, Somogyi P.
column10: Physiological properties of anatomically identified axo-axonic cells in the rat hippocampus.

column5: "Recordings were judged acceptable for the analysis of membrane properties when cells had a stable resting membrane potential (RMP) exceeding -55 mV without requiring steady hyperpolarizing current injection. Thus, from a total of 17 cells, 3 cells were subsequently rejected from analysis. Apart from being relatively depolarized, these cells showed other signs of neuronal injury, such as low input resistance or wide and low-amplitude action potentials. The remainder <% 4036 %> (n = 14) had a mean RMP of -65.1 +/- 3.9 mV"
column9: Buhl EH, Han ZS, Lörinczi Z, Stezhka VV, Karnup SV, Somogyi P.
column10: Physiological properties of anatomically identified axo-axonic cells in the rat hippocampus.
column15: In the Hippocampome, the resting membrane potential (Vrest) is defined relative to zero.

column5: "FIG. 5. Responses of 2 different axo-axonic cells to the injection of suprathreshold depolarizing current pulses. Increasing the current amplitude invariably resulted in higher firing rates. ... D and E: in contrast, some axo-axonic cells <% 4036 %>, here from subfield CA1 (membrane potential -72 mV), were characterized by a marked attenuation of their firing rate. During the period of strongest adaptation the action potentials were riding on a depolarizing wave. Also note the concomitant decrease in action potential amplitude."
column9: Buhl EH, Han ZS, Lörinczi Z, Stezhka VV, Karnup SV, Somogyi P.
column10: Physiological properties of anatomically identified axo-axonic cells in the rat hippocampus.

column5: "Figure 2. PCs [pyramidal cells] <% 4000 %> and RGCs [radiatum giant cells] <% 4054 %> [in CA1] have similar intrinsic ﬁring patterns. Current–clamp recordings were obtained from an exemplary PC (A) and RGC (B). The characteristic ﬁring response to brief (5 msec) and long (1600 msec) positive current pulses are shown in a and b, respectively. Both the PC and the RGC ﬁred a single action potential in response to brief current pulses and an accommodating train of action potentials in response to long current pulses. The resting potentials of the neurons in this and in the following ﬁgures is indicated to the left of the top traces."
column9: Kirson ED, Yaari Y.
column10: Unique properties of NMDA receptors enhance synaptic excitation of radiatum giant cells in rat hippocampus.
column18: One distinction between PLPs <% 4054 %> and pyramidal neurons <% 4000 %> is apparent in the scarcity of pyramidal neuron projections to the olfactory bulb. This pattern of projection is similar to the RGC, a class of principal neurons in the hippocampus (Gulyas et al.1998; Christie et al. 2000; Kirson & Yaari, 2000; Savic & Sciancalepore, 2001). RGCs also project to the olfactory bulb, and make asymmetrical synapses with other neurons (Gulyas et al. 1998). Most RGCs also have two prominent apical dendrites that project to the SR/SLM. The somata of these neurons normally have the shape of an inverted triangle, and have little basal branching (Gulyas et al.1998; Kirson & Yaari, 2000). A minority of RGCs have been described with a more typical pyramidal appearance, particularly the P-cell-like class described byGulyas et al. (1998) Although PLPs are probably a subclass of RGCs, we chose a distinct nomenclature to emphasize the significantly different morphology of the PLP compared to the typical non-pyramidal RGC morphology.

column5: "Figure 8. Inhibitory connection from an O/A [oriens/alveus] interneuron <% 4055 %> [in CA1] to a stratum pyramidale interneuron. Depolarization-induced firing in the O/A interneuron (middle trace)  produced a 10 mV hyperpolarization in the stratum pyramidale interneuron (upper trace). The membrane recovered to prestimulation level (dotted line, upper trace) 125 msec after the end of  the burst in the O/A interneuron. Stratum pyramidale interneuron RMP [resting membrane potential], -40 mV; O/A interneuron RMP, -80 mV."
column9: Lacaille JC, Mueller AL, Kunkel DD, Schwartzkroin PA.
column10: Local circuit interactions between oriens/alveus interneurons and CA1 pyramidal cells in hippocampal slices: electrophysiology and morphology.

column5: "Figure 9. HRP[horseradish peroxidase]-filled O/A [oriens/alveus] interneuron <% 4055%> [in CA1]. A, O/A interneuron response to depolarizing current prior to HRP injection. An intrasomatic depolarizing current pulse (0.5 nA, 100 msec; lower trace) produces a train of action potentials (upper trace) typical of the O/A interneurons. Note the AHP [afterhyperpolarization] following the end of the burst. Dotted line is resting membrane potential. O/A interneuron RMP [resting membrane potential], - 55 mV."

column5: "Figure 7. Neurophysiological properties of visually identiﬁed hippocampal EGFP[enhanced green fluorescent protein]-expressing interneurons <% 4066 %> [in CA1]. ... b, Response of the R-LM cell of a to depolarizing current injections (0.05– 0.15 nA, 0.05 nA increments). Trains of action potentials were elicited in response to square wave depolarizing current steps that increased in frequency as the depolarizations increased. As was typical for EGFP-expressing interneurons, this neuron showed little, if any, spike frequency adaptation (accommodation). c, R-LM cell response to squarewave hyperpolarizing current injections (-0.20 to -0.05 nA, 0.05 nA increments). Note the time-dependent inward rectiﬁcation (depolarizing "sag") typical of this interneuronal cell type. ... Input resistance: b, 150 MOhm; c, 300 MOhm; ... Resting membrane potential: b, -69 mV; c, -67 mV; ... Calibration: 200 msec, 20 mV (shown in c for b, c; e for e, f ). All recordings were performed at room temperature."

column5: "Figure 5-24. Differential axon targeting of various inhibitory intemeurons. Three types of interneuron are shown, each with a cell body and dendrites in the stratum oriens of CA1 but having distinct axonal projection patterns and physiological properties. A. ...  Upon injection of a depolarizing current pulse, O-LM intemeurons <% 4069 %> exhibit an accommodating train of action potentials followed by a slow AHP. A prominent sag indicative of Ih is present upon hyperpolarization (A2)."

column5: "Fig. 3. Multiple action potential initiation sites in oriens-alveus interneurons <% 4069 %> [in CA1]. (A) Simultaneous current-clamp (CC) recordings from a dendrite (red traces) and soma (black traces) in two different neurons (middle panel, top and bottom). First action potentials in a train are shown on an expanded time scale in the right panel. Schemes on the left illustrate the locations of axon initial segments as revealed by correlated morphological analysis. The depolarizing current (100 ms, 100 pA) was injected into the soma in both cases."

column5: "Fig. 4. Electrophysiological properties of pro-CCK[cholecystokinin]-immunopositive interneurones. Comparison of the active membrane properties of two basket cells <% 4079 %> (A and B, cell identities 271100/4, P16, and 281100/4, P17, respectively) to two Schaffer collateral-associated cells <% 4015 %> [in CA1] (C and D, cell identities 310800/1, P12, and 040900/2, P16, respectively). (A 1 , C 1 ) Voltage responses of a basket and Schaffer collateral-associated cell, to hyperpolarising (-100 to -25 pA) and a small depolarising (+50 and +25 pA, respectively) current steps. Voltage responses to hyperpolarising current steps in the Schaffer collateral-associated cell show a pronounced rectification, or ‘sag’, which is present to a lesser degree in the basket cell. Note how the depolarising rebound potentials at the step offset of the two largest voltage responses in the Schaffer collateral-associated cell are able to generate rebound action potentials. (A2, C2) Current-voltage plots of peak (_) and steady-state (_) hyperpolarising voltage responses as depicted in A1 and C1. (A3, C3) Expanded voltage traces (as marked by asterisks in A1 and C1, respectively) showing a single action potential and the characteristic triphasic after-hyperpolarisation following it. (B1, D1) Voltage responses of a basket and Schaffer collateral-associated cell to a large (+325 and +150 pA, respectively) depolarising current step. (B2, D2) Plot of the change in ISI [inter-spike interval] against ISI number in the spike train for the voltage traces shown in B 1 and D 1 . Letters (a, b) represent the points from which spike adaptation ratios were calculated relative to point c (see main text for details). Vertical calibration bar in A1 also applies to A3, C1 and C3 . Horizontal calibration bar in A1 also applies to B1 , C1 and D1. Horizontal calibration bar in A3 also applies to C3. Vertical calibration bar in B1 also applies to D1."
column9: Cope DW, Maccaferri G, Márton LF, Roberts JD, Cobden PM, Somogyi P.
column10: Cholecystokinin-immunopositive basket and Schaffer collateral-associated interneurones target different domains of pyramidal cells in the CA1 area of the rat hippocampus.

column5: "Figure 6. Synaptic Transmission and Reconstruction of a Reciprocally Connected Ivy <% 4081 %> and Pyramidal Cell Pair in the CA1 Region of the Hippocampus (A) Reconstruction (from a 450-[micro]m-thick slice) of the Ivy cell (soma/dendrites in orange, axon in yellow) and the pyramidal cell (soma/dendrites in light blue, axon in white). A large portion of the interneuron’s axonal arbor is located in stratum pyramidale and stratum oriens, with very few collaterals extending into stratum radiatum and alveus. (B) Responses of the Ivy cell to injected current pulses, demonstrating the frequency adaptation seen in these interneurons. (C) Action potentials elicited by just suprathreshold current pulses in the pyramidal cell (mauve trace), the Ivy cell (orange trace), and a bistratiﬁed cell recorded in another experiment (gray trace) are superimposed. The Ivy cell action potential is similar in width to that of the pyramidal cell and is considerably broader than the action potential in the bistratiﬁed cell. (D) Composite averages of the excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) elicited by the pyramidal cell in the Ivy cell, demonstrating the strong paired pulse and brief train depression typical of these inputs. (E) Composite averages of the inhibitory postsynaptic potentials (IPSPs) elicited by the Ivy cell in the pyramidal cell, demonstrating the typically slow time course and paired pulse depression of the IPSPs. (F) Photomicrographs of the Ivy cell at two different magniﬁcations to illustrate a putative synaptic input from the pyramidal cell to the interneuron (red arrows). Two such putative contacts were identiﬁed. The lower bouton and contact site is directly above the dendrite and not visible on this micrograph. Vertical scale bars: (B), 20 mV; (C), 20 mV; (D) EPSPs, 2 mV; spike, 20 mV; (E) spike, 20 mV; IPSP, 1 mV. Horizontal scale bars: (A), 100 [micro]m; (B), 40 ms; (C), 2 ms; (D), 20 ms; (E), 50 ms; (F) left, 5 [micro]m; right, 2.5 [micro]m."

column5: "Figure 2. column5: "The spike amplitudes [of the CA1 horizontal oriens-alveus neurons] <% 4089 %> were 58.75 +/- 7.2 mV (overshoot, 8 +/- 4.5 mV) and firing showed less spike frequency adaptation or accommodation than in pyramidal cells (Maccaferri & McBain, 1995; see Zhang & McBain, 1995 a,b for complete description of K+ currents associated with the spike AHP)."

column5: "The horizontal O-A [oriens-alveus] interneurones <% 4089 %> were electrophysiologically distinct from the pyramidal cells in the briefer time course of their action potentials (width at half-amplitude, 0.6 +/- 0.3 ms) and their large, fast spike afterhyperpolarizations (AHPs), which were 16.1 +/- 10.7 mV in amplitude (spike threshold to AHP peak) with a width at half-amplitude of 6.58 +/- 2.7 ms (shown in detail in Fig. 2D)."

column5: "Fig. 4. Burst ﬁring cell ﬁring in the absence of any ﬁeld activity, suggesting that burst ﬁring cells <% 5001 %> [in the subiculum] may function as pacemaker neurons for the generation of epileptiform activity. Simple and compound bursts are seen in each sweep (12.8 seconds per sweep). A simultaneous ﬁeld potential recording showed no activity. Membrane depolarization with current injection converted the cell’s ﬁring from bursts to single spiking at a higher rate. Occasional bursts were still seen, suggesting that some bursts may have been synaptically driven (see Stewart, 1997). At less positive potentials, at rest and at potentials tested that were hyperpolarized from rest, burst were seen. Reference line is approximately 230 mV. Calibration: 40 mV, 1 sec."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6002 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). A: Input resistance. LV [Layer V] neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to neurons in all other layers. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6002 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... B: The time constant (tau) differs signiﬁcantly between layers, with principal neurons in all layers having a longer time constant compared with LII. Time constant is deﬁned as the time for the voltage deﬂection to reach 63% of its maximal value in response to a negative current step. We measured it for the step that lead to a steady state voltage deﬂection between -70 and -75 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6002 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... C: The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower for principal neurons in LI  and LII compared to all other layers. The sag ratio was computed by dividing the maximal voltage deﬂection by the mean steady state membrane potential, which was between -70 and -75 mV. D: The rebound amplitude is signiﬁcantly bigger in LI and LII principal neurons compared with that observed for principal neurons in the other layers. The amplitude is the difference between the maximum positive voltage deﬂection after offset of a negative current step and the resting membrane potential."

column5: "FIGURE 6. Average AP [action potential] amplitudes in response to +200 pA pulses measured by computing the difference between the AP threshold and the peak of the voltage deﬂection. A–E: Represent the results for the [MEC] principal neurons of the different layers [of the entorhinal cortex], (A) LI [layer I], (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV <%6002 %>, and (E) LVI. column5: "FIGURE 10. Morphology and physiology of MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6002 %>. ... C: Weak depolarization induces relatively regular ﬁring in LV neurons. Positive 200 pA depolarization induces SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a constant decrease in the AP [action potential] amplitude. The majority of neurons do not have membrane potential oscillations and a resonance. C1-4. Response properties of one typical principal neuron in MEC LV principal. C5-9. Response properties of another typical principal neuron in MEC LV. C 1 and C5 show responses to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. C2, 6, 7 show three representative voltage responses to a +/-200 pA step of 1 s. C1, 2, 5, 6, 7. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP afterpotentials. The neuron illustrated in C1-4 also shows a DAP whereas the one illustrated in C5-9 has no DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]. Note that the presence or absence of a DAP is not related to any of the other response properties. Below the inset in C1 the percentage of all LV neurons with a DAP in response to a small current step is indicated and below the inset in C2 the percentage of all neurons that show a DAP after a +200 pA step is indicated. The percentages of all neurons that lack a DAP after a small or +200 pA step are indicated below the insets of C 5 and C 6/7 , respectively. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6003 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... B: The time constant (tau) differs signiﬁcantly between layers, with principal neurons in all layers having a longer time constant compared with LII. Time constant is deﬁned as the time for the voltage deﬂection to reach 63% of its maximal value in response to a negative current step. We measured it for the step that lead to a steady state voltage deﬂection between -70 and -75 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 5. Histograms summarizing the ISIs of all layers in response to (A) a current step inducing at least six APs, and (B) to a 1200 pA step. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. The results for the principal neu- rons of the different layers are presented in the rows. B: Positive 200 pA injection leads to statistically signiﬁcant differences in the ISI in all layers, except LVI. This indicates that principal neurons in all layers show SFA, except for LVI. Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). (A) Input resistance. column5: "FIGURE 5. Histograms summarizing the ISIs of all layers in response to (A) a current step inducing at least six APs, and (B) to a 1200 pA step. A Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (repeated measures ANOVA). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N5). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. The results for the principal neu- rons of the different layers are presented in the rows. The ISI is given for the 1st and 2nd AP, the 2nd and 3rd AP, the 4th and 5th AP and the last and last-1 AP if available. ... B: Positive 200 pA injection leads to statistically signiﬁcant differences in the ISI in all layers, except LVI. This indicates that principal neurons in all layers show SFA, except for LVI. SFA is the strongest in LV compared with the other layers."

A–E: Represent the results for the [MEC] principal neurons of the different layers [of the entorhinal cortex], (A) LI [layer I], (B) LII <% 6005 %>, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. The sizes of the APs do not decrease in LI and LIII principal neurons. column5: "FIGURE 5. Interspike-intervals (ISI) of neurons in all layers in response to a 1200 pA step in (A) LI, (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6008 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). (A) Input resistance. LV [layer V] principal neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to LII principal neurons. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6008 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (B) The time constant (tau) differs between layers, with LV having the longest time constant that is signiﬁcantly different compared to LII. Time constant is the time it takes for the voltage deﬂection in response to a negative current step to reach 63% of its maximal value. We measured it for the step that leads to a steady state voltage deﬂection between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6008 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (C) The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower in LI and LII principal neurons compared to that of LIII and LVI principal neurons. The sag ratio of LII principal neurons is also lower compared to LV principal neurons. The sag ratio was computed by dividing the maximal voltage deﬂection by the mean steady state membrane potential, which was between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 10. Morphology and physiology of MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6021 %>. ... C: Weak depolarization induces relatively regular ﬁring in LV neurons. Positive 200 pA depolarization induces SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a constant decrease in the AP [action potential] amplitude. The majority of neurons do not have membrane potential oscillations and a resonance. C1-4. Response properties of one typical principal neuron in MEC LV principal. ... C1 and C5 show responses to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. ... C1, 2, 5, 6, 7. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP afterpotentials. The neuron illustrated in C1-4 also shows a DAP whereas the one illustrated in C5-9 has no DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]. Note that the presence or absence of a DAP is not related to any of the other response properties. Below the inset in C1 the percentage of all LV neurons with a DAP in response to a small current step is indicated and below the inset in C2 the percentage of all neurons that show a DAP after a +200 pA step is indicated. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6023 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). A: Input resistance. LV [Layer V] neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to neurons in all other layers. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6023 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... B: The time constant (tau) differs signiﬁcantly between layers, with principal neurons in all layers having a longer time constant compared with LII. Time constant is deﬁned as the time for the voltage deﬂection to reach 63% of its maximal value in response to a negative current step. We measured it for the step that lead to a steady state voltage deﬂection between -70 and -75 mV."
column9: Canto CB, Witter MP.

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6023 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... C: The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower for principal neurons in LI  and LII compared to all other layers. The sag ratio was computed by dividing the maximal voltage deﬂection by the mean steady state membrane potential, which was between -70 and -75 mV. D: The rebound amplitude is signiﬁcantly bigger in LI and LII principal neurons compared with that observed for principal neurons in the other layers. The amplitude is the difference between the maximum positive voltage deﬂection after offset of a negative current step and the resting membrane potential."

column5: "FIGURE 4. Summary histograms of action potential properties of principal neurons <% 6023 %>  in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... D: The AP half-width measured at 50% of the AP amplitude of the ﬁrst AP in response to a weak current step, is signiﬁcantly smaller in LI and LII neurons compared with all other layers. column5: "FIGURE 6. Average AP [action potential] amplitudes in response to +200 pA pulses measured by computing the difference between the AP threshold and the peak of the voltage deﬂection. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (repeated measures ANOVA [analysis of variance]). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. A–E: Represent the results for the [MEC] principal neurons of the different layers, (A) LI [layer I], (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV <% 6023 %>, and (E) LVI. The sizes of the APs do not decrease in LI and LIII principal neurons. LII, LV, and LVI principal neurons show a signiﬁcant decrease in the amplitude from the 1st to the last AP respectively, with LV neurons showing the strongest decrease in amplitude."

column5: "FIGURE 10. Morphology and physiology of MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6023 %>. ... C: Weak depolarization induces relatively regular ﬁring in LV neurons. Positive 200 pA depolarization induces SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a constant decrease in the AP [action potential] amplitude. The majority of neurons do not have membrane potential oscillations and a resonance. C1-4. Response properties of one typical principal neuron in MEC LV principal. ... C1 and C5 show responses to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. ... C1, 2, 5, 6, 7. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP afterpotentials. The neuron illustrated in C1-4 also shows a DAP whereas the one illustrated in C5-9 has no DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]. Note that the presence or absence of a DAP is not related to any of the other response properties. Below the inset in C1 the percentage of all LV neurons with a DAP in response to a small current step is indicated and below the inset in C2 the percentage of all neurons that show a DAP after a +200 pA step is indicated. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces."

column5: "FIGURE 5. Interspike-intervals (ISI) of neurons in all layers in response to a 1200 pA step in (A) LI, (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. The ISI is given for the 1st and 2nd AP, the 2nd and 3rd AP, the 4th and 5th AP and the last and last-1 AP, if available. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (repeated measures ANOVA). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N5). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Positive 200 pA injection leads to statistically signiﬁcant differences in the ISI in all layers, except LVI. This indicates that all layers show SFA, except LVI."

column5: "FIGURE 6. (A-E) Results for the [LEC] principal neurons of the different layers, (A) LI [Layer I], (B) LII, (C) LIII <% 6025 %>, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. column5: "FIGURE 8. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LIII [layer III] principal neurons <% 6025 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1,4 . Voltage responses of two typical LEC LIII principal neurons in response to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. C2,5. The voltage response to a +/-200 pA step of 1 s. C1,2,4,5 . Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP [action potential] after potentials. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces. LIII principal neurons ﬁre regular in response to a weak and a +200pA current step with 50% of the neurons showing an increase in the AP frequency throughout the ﬁrst three APs. LIII principal neurons do not have a DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6031 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. column5: "FIGURE 10. Morphology and physiology of MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6033 %>. ... C: Weak depolarization induces relatively regular ﬁring in LV neurons. Positive 200 pA depolarization induces SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a constant decrease in the AP [action potential] amplitude. The majority of neurons do not have membrane potential oscillations and a resonance. C1-4. Response properties of one typical principal neuron in MEC LV principal. C5-9. Response properties of another typical principal neuron in MEC LV. C 1 and C5 show responses to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. C2, 6, 7 show three representative voltage responses to a +/-200 pA step of 1 s. C1, 2, 5, 6, 7. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP afterpotentials. The neuron illustrated in C1-4 also shows a DAP whereas the one illustrated in C5-9 has no DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]. Note that the presence or absence of a DAP is not related to any of the other response properties. Below the inset in C1 the percentage of all LV neurons with a DAP in response to a small current step is indicated and below the inset in C2 the percentage of all neurons that show a DAP after a +200 pA step is indicated. The percentages of all neurons that lack a DAP after a small or +200 pA step are indicated below the insets of C 5 and C 6/7 , respectively. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces."
column9: Canto CB, Witter MP.
column10: Cellular properties of principal neurons in the rat entorhinal cortex. II. The medial entorhinal cortex.

Note that the presence or absence of a DAP is not related to any of the other response properties. Below the inset in C1 the percentage of all LV neurons with a DAP in response to a small current step is indicated and below the inset in C2 the percentage of all neurons that show a DAP after a +200 pA step is indicated. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Histograms of intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all MEC [medial entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6052 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. column5: "FIGURE 5. Histograms summarizing the ISIs of all layers in response to (A) a current step inducing at least six APs, and (B) to a 1200 pA step. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. The results for the principal neurons of the different layers are presented in the rows. The ISI is given for the 1st and 2nd AP, the 2nd and 3rd AP, the 4th and 5th AP and the last and last-1 AP if available. ... B: Positive 200 pA injection leads to statistically signiﬁcant differences in the ISI in all layers, except LVI. This indicates that principal neurons in all layers show SFA, except for LVI. column5: "FIGURE 6. Average AP [action potential] amplitudes in response to +200 pA pulses measured by computing the difference between the AP threshold and the peak of the voltage deﬂection. On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. A–E: Represent the results for the [MEC] principal neurons of the different layers [of the entorhinal cortex], (A) LI [layer I], (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI <% 6052 %>. The sizes of the APs do not decrease in LI and LIII principal neurons. LII, LV, and LVI principal neurons show a signiﬁcant decrease in the amplitude from the 1st to the last AP respectively, with LV neurons showing the strongest decrease in amplitude."

column5: "FIGURE 5. Interspike-intervals (ISI) of neurons in all layers in response to a 1200 pA step in (A) LI, (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. The ISI is given for the 1st and 2nd AP, the 2nd and 3rd AP, the 4th and 5th AP and the last and last-1 AP, if available. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (repeated measures ANOVA). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N5). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Positive 200 pA injection leads to statistically signiﬁcant differences in the ISI in all layers, except LVI. This indicates that all layers show SFA, except LVI."

column5: "FIGURE 6. (A-E) Results for the [LEC] principal neurons of the different layers, (A) LI [Layer I], (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI <% 6078 %>. column5: "FIGURE 10. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LVI [Layer VI] principal neurons <% 6078 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1. column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6082 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). (A) Input resistance. LV [layer V] principal neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to LII principal neurons. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6082 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (B) The time constant (tau) differs between layers, with LV having the longest time constant that is signiﬁcantly different compared to LII. Time constant is the time it takes for the voltage deﬂection in response to a negative current step to reach 63% of its maximal value. We measured it for the step that leads to a steady state voltage deﬂection between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6082 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. (C) The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower in LI and LII principal neurons compared to that of LIII and LVI principal neurons. The sag ratio of LII principal neurons is also lower compared to LV principal neurons. The sag ratio was computed by dividing the maximal voltage deﬂection by the mean steady state membrane potential, which was between 270 and 275 mV."

Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (C) The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower in LI and LII principal neurons compared to that of LIII and LVI principal neurons. The sag ratio of LII principal neurons is also lower compared to LV principal neurons. The sag ratio was computed by dividing the maximal voltage deﬂection by the mean steady state membrane potential, which was between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 9. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6086 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1,4. Voltage responses of two typical LEC LV principal neurons in response to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. C2,5. The voltage response to a +/-200 pA step of 1 s. C1,2,4,5. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP [action potential] after potentials. Below insets of C1 and C2 the percentages of neurons without a DAP [depolarizing afterpotential] and below insets of C4 and C5 the percentages of neurons with a DAP are indicated, in response to a small (C1 and 4) and +200pA step (C 2 and 5). ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces. LV neurons show prominent SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a decrease in the spike amplitude. Only the ﬁrst spike in a spike train in LV neurons shows a DAP."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6092 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). (A) Input resistance. LV [layer V] principal neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to LII principal neurons. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."
column9: Canto CB, Witter MP.
column10: Cellular properties of principal neurons in the rat entorhinal cortex. I. The lateral entorhinal cortex.

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6092 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (B) The time constant (tau) differs between layers, with LV having the longest time constant that is signiﬁcantly different compared to LII. Time constant is the time it takes for the voltage deﬂection in response to a negative current step to reach 63% of its maximal value. We measured it for the step that leads to a steady state voltage deﬂection between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 8. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LIII [layer III] principal neurons <% 6092 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1,4 . Voltage responses of two typical LEC LIII principal neurons in response to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. C2,5. The voltage response to a +/-200 pA step of 1 s. C1,2,4,5 . Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP [action potential] after potentials. ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces. LIII principal neurons ﬁre regular in response to a weak and a +200pA current step with 50% of the neurons showing an increase in the AP frequency throughout the ﬁrst three APs. LIII principal neurons do not have a DAP [depolarizing afterpotential]."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6094 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). (A) Input resistance. LV [layer V] principal neurons have a signiﬁcantly higher input resistance compared to LII principal neurons. Input resistance is measured by dividing the amplitude of the voltage response with that of the current step injected."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6094 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (Kruskal-Wallis followed by Mann-Whitney U-tests) or with # ((M)ANOVA [multivariate analysis of variance] followed by post hoc Bonferroni tests). Number of neurons per layer is indicated with (N=). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N=). ... (B) The time constant (tau) differs between layers, with LV having the longest time constant that is signiﬁcantly different compared to LII. Time constant is the time it takes for the voltage deﬂection in response to a negative current step to reach 63% of its maximal value. We measured it for the step that leads to a steady state voltage deﬂection between 270 and 275 mV."

column5: "FIGURE 3. Intrinsic membrane properties of principal neurons in all LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] layers <% 6094 %>. Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. (C) The sag ratio is signiﬁcantly lower in LI and LII principal neurons compared to that of LIII and LVI principal neurons. The sag ratio of LII principal neurons is also lower compared to LV principal neurons. column5: "FIGURE 7. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LII [Layer II] principal neurons <% 6094 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1,4. column5: "FIGURE 5. Interspike-intervals (ISI) of neurons in all layers in response to a 1200 pA step in (A) LI, (B) LII, (C) LIII, (D) LV, and (E) LVI. The ISI is given for the 1st and 2nd AP, the 2nd and 3rd AP, the 4th and 5th AP and the last and last-1 AP, if available. Signiﬁcance is indicated with * (repeated measures ANOVA). On the y-axis, the parameter measured is indicated and the total number of neurons in which this parameter was measured (N5). Data are averages with the error bars indicating s.e.m. column5: "FIGURE 9. Morphology and physiology of LEC [lateral entorhinal cortex] LV [layer V] principal neurons <% 6095 %>. ... (C) Electrophysiological properties. C1,4. Voltage responses of two typical LEC LV principal neurons in response to a weak hyperpolarizing and depolarizing 1 s step just reaching ﬁring threshold. ... C1,2,4,5. Insets show a zoom in of 20 ms, displaying the AP [action potential] after potentials. Below insets of C1 and C2 the percentages of neurons without a DAP [depolarizing afterpotential] and below insets of C4 and C5 the percentages of neurons with a DAP are indicated, in response to a small (C1 and 4) and +200pA step (C 2 and 5). ... In all subﬁgures the average membrane potential is indicated right below the individual voltage traces. LV neurons show prominent SFA [spike-frequency adaptation], sometimes correlated with a decrease in the spike amplitude. Only the ﬁrst spike in a spike train in LV neurons shows a DAP."
